qas.question: What did comics have in the United States because of cultural roots?
Who thought pop culture was a risk?
What was thought to be only good for children and those who could not read or write?
What did comics have in the United States because of sports roots?
What did comics not have in the United States because of cultural roots?
Who thought pop culture wasn't at risk?
What was thought to be bad for children and those who could not read or write?
What was thought to be only good for children and those who could read or write?

context: <a2_0>Comics<a2_0/> in the US has had a <a0_0><b3_0><b4_0>lowbrow reputation<b4_0/><b3_0/><a0_0/> stemming from its roots in mass culture; <a1_0><b5_0>cultural elites<b5_0/><a1_0/> sometimes saw popular culture as threatening culture and society. In the latter half of the 20th century, popular culture won greater acceptance, and the lines between high and low culture began to blur. <b6_0><b7_0>Comics<b7_0/><b6_0/> nevertheless continued to be stigmatized, as the medium was seen as entertainment for children and illiterates.
